title: Delete only tweets belonging to a certain timeline on loading page 1
message:
Delete only tweets belonging to a certain timeline on loading page 1

Now, if the same tweet is fetched for a different timeline (e.g.
home timeline instead of user timeline), then the "type" field of
this tweet will be overriden in the database, i.e. the full
timelines are not maintained in the database. This problem could
be solved by  making the primary key a composite of the tweet ID
and the type.

The reason for keeping similar tweets belonging to a different
timeline in the database is that the different timelines can be
restored in offline mode.

title: Add UserTimelineFragment to ProfileActivity
message:
Add UserTimelineFragment to ProfileActivity

Works so far. Things to improve:

- If page 1 of a timeline is loaded, delete only the Tweet entries
  from the database belonging to this timeline (type)
- The "last update" preference for the user timeline makes no sense,
  because there's a separate user timeline for every user
- ProfileActivity crashes on screen rotation, because of
  "fragment not attached to activity"

title: Improve UI of ProfileActivity (including profile banner)
message: Improve UI of ProfileActivity (including profile banner)

title: Launch ProfileActivity on any profile image click in RecyclerView
message:
Launch ProfileActivity on any profile image click in RecyclerView

The click on the profile image is detected in the adapter for the
RecyclerView items. From there it is communicated via a listener
callback (the adapter has a setOnProfileImageClickListener method
used by the TimelineFragment) to the TimelineFragment. In this
callback, the fragment communicates the clicked user via another
callback (the TimelineFragment has a TimelineFragmentListener
implemented by the TimelineActivity) to the TimelineActivity.
Finally, the TimelineActivity launches the ProfileActivity by
passing the User object whose profile image has been clicked.

title: Detecting clicks on ImageViews in RecyclerView
message:
Detecting clicks on ImageViews in RecyclerView

...in order to launch ProfileActivity for the user whose image has
been clicked in the RecyclerView.

title: Add ProfileActivity for displaying the profile of a user
message:
Add ProfileActivity for displaying the profile of a user

Currently, displaying the profile of the authenticatd user via
an app bar menu item.

title: Introduce OfflineModeManager; improve LoginManager
message:
Introduce OfflineModeManager; improve LoginManager

The LoginManager is better integrated and has a method for
determining the current user, and a callback for success and failure
that must be passed to this method.

The LoginManager and OfflineModeManager can be called from anywhere
in the application for determining the current user and whether
the app is in online or offline mode. However, it's necessary that
both managers are properly initialised at some point ("determineX"
methods).

title: Home and mentions timeline as fragments in ViewPager
message:
Home and mentions timeline as fragments in ViewPager

The TimelineActivity now holds a ViewPager, and the individual
timelines are implemented as fragments. The TimelineActivity
initialises the ViewPager with two fragments for the home and
mentions timeline.

Further changes:
- Introduce LoginManager for holding reference to currently
  authenticated user (and more?)

Next steps:
- Improve abstract class TimelineFragment
- Introduce OfflineModeManager to hold flag whether the app is in
  offline mode (and more?)
- Use EventBus for communication between components

Menu item for logging out from Twitter

On logout, redirection to LoginActivity.

title: Pass offline mode to ComposeActivity
message:
Pass offline mode to ComposeActivity

If the ComposeActivity is launched in offline mode, the input
widgets (EditText and Button) are disabled, and the offline
indicator bar is displayed.

Also: whenever the first page of tweets is loaded, the current
time is saved in the SharedPreferences, and this time is
displayed as "last update" in the offline indicator in
TimelineActivity.

title: Save current user in SharedPreferences in TimelineActivity
message:
Save current user in SharedPreferences in TimelineActivity

The currently authenticated user is queried on activity creation
and saved in SharedPreferences. If the app is opened offline
(offline mode), then the current user is read from the SharedPrefs
rather than from the server.

Also. pass the current user to the ComposeActivity so that it
does not need to be fetched from the server again there.

message: Add offline mode indicator

title: Save fetched tweets in database and provide "offline mode"
message:
Save fetched tweets in database and provide "offline mode"

On creation of TimelineActivity, if there is internet connection,
the home timeline tweets are fetched from the server. If there
is no internet connection, then the currently saved tweets
from the database are displayed.

Several UI improvements

- Allow cancelling composing a tweet by providing a "Back" navigation
  icon in ComposeActivity
- Use "bigger" (73x73px) profile image sizes
- Enable navigation icon in ComposeActivity to go back to
  TimelineActivity by only "re-starting" rather than "re-creating" TimelineActivity

- Test if username in data binding variable in XML layout is null, which
  is the case when the API call didn't yet return

title: Successfully accessing Twiter API and getting home timeline
message:
Successfully accessing Twiter API and getting home timeline

On clicking the button on the login screen, a web browser app is
launched with a Twitter authorisation page in which the user can
enter their username and password in order to authorise our app
to make access the Twitter API on their behalf (e.g. reading their
home timeline, i.e. own posts and posts of followed people).

From this point on, we apparently have an access token which is
sent with every request, and every request is specific to this user
that initially authorised our app.

We can then make all the API calls as defined on
https://dev.twitter.com/rest/reference

Bad thing: the Codepath android-oauth-handler
(https://github.com/codepath/android-oauth-handler) which is used
by this app skeleton uses Android-Async-HTTP which cannot be
combined with Stetho for monitoring the HTTP API requests and
responses.

Maybe it would be better to only use ScribeJava for the OAuth stuff
and then use Retrofit with OkHttp for the HTTP requests, which can
be combined with Stetho.
